awd_titl_txt: WoU-MMA: Gravitational Wave Coupling with Inhomogeneous Plasma and Asymptotic Theory of Polarization Effects in Curved Spacetime
awd_abstract_narration:
Scientists have long predicted that disturbances in the fabric of spacetime, called gravitational waves (GWs), can be generated by binary stars and propagate across the Universe with speeds close to the speed of light. Recently, these waves have been detected, resulting in the 2017 Nobel Prize in Physics. This discovery opens new opportunities to study fascinating astronomical processes which so far have only been hypothesized, and may help us to better understand the Universe. Some GWs have been detected in parallel with bursts of electromagnetic radiation, and correlations between gravitational and electromagnetic signals can tell us even more than gravitational signals alone. To infer information from these correlations, we need to understand how GWs and electromagnetic radiation are coupled in plasmas surrounding GW sources.  This project is aimed towards developing the first comprehensive theory to address this complicated correlation problem. The project is directly aligned with the goals of NSF's "Windows on the Universe: The Era of Multi-Messenger Astrophysics" Big Idea, because understanding of how GW waves affect a plasma is necessary for astrophysicists to interpret the origin of electromagnetic radiation from GW sources. The project bridges plasma physics and gravitational physics and a graduate student will be trained in the new multidisciplinary area at the intersection of these two fields.

This project will allow a rigorous derivation of the plasma susceptibilities with respect to a combination of metric and electromagnetic oscillations. Using a variational approach, geometrical-optics equations for linear plasma waves coupled with metric oscillations will be formulated. In doing so, nonlinear (ponderomotive) forces produced by gravitational radiation will also be studied. The usual assumption of transverse polarization for the metric oscillations is not invoked, so it is expected that the estimates for the GW-plasma coupling coefficients will be significantly improved. After exploring the resulting dispersion relations, both analytically and by using particle-in-cell simulations, the energy transfer from metric oscillations to plasma will be estimated. As a spinoff, the deviation of electromagnetic rays from null geodesics in prescribed spacetime (the "spin Hall effect of light") will be rigorously calculated for a general metric for the first time.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The recent detection of gravitational waves accompanied by electromagnetic radiation has ushered a new era of multi-messenger astronomy. The idea behind this venture is to use observations of gravitational and electromagnetic signals synergistically to learn more about sources of these signals, which can range from compact object mergers to early Universe, than each signal type allows individually. However, utilizing this synergy requires that one understands the interaction between the multiple messengers, specifically, interactions between gravitational and electromagnetic waves in plasma.

Unfortunately, even the simplest, linear, gravitational waves in plasmas are described by extremely cumbersome equations. This prevented systematic theoretical studies of these waves in the past, in striking contrast with electromagnetic waves, whose basic properties (dispersion, polarization, envelope dynamics) in plasmas have long been accessible. We have developed an alternative, variational, approach to this problem and have been able to rigorously describe the properties of gravitational waves in plasma for the first time.

Our approach is based on studying particles' trajectories averaged over particles' wave-driven oscillations. We have shown that these trajectories are subject to a "gravitational ponderomotive effect"; that is, the time-average effect of a rapidly oscillating wave on a particle is equivalent to particle's interaction with a slowly varying effective field, which we have calculated explicitly. For the commonly known gravitational waves in vacuum, this interaction is equivalent to that with an effective background metric that depends on the wave intensity. We have shown that this interaction can be a noticeable heating mechanism for plasmas near sources of intense gravitational radiation. We have also shown how the properties of this single-particle effect can be linked to the "gravitoelectromagnetic" susceptibility of plasma and studied these properties in detail for nonmagnetized plasmas in particular. This forms a foundation of a systematic theory of gravitational waves in plasmas (both linear and quasilinear), of the kind that was previously available only for electromagnetic waves.

However, we have also found that gravitational waves are, in some ways, very special.

First of all, the presence of plasma changes not only the dispersion of waves but also the background spacetime. As we have shown, the modification of this spacetime makes it generally impossible to approach the effect of matter on gravitational ways using ray optics, a tool that has been commonly used so far; that is, interaction with matter is as important as diffraction. However, exceptions are possible in special cases when gravitational waves are strongly coupled to plasma. One example such "gravitostatic modes" is the well-known Jeans instability, which we have explained as a "longitudinal" gravitational wave that is naturally captured by relativistic theory on the same footing with the "usual" gravitational waves. More generally, the polarization of gravitational modes in plasma can vary continuously with the plasma parameters, so it is not restricted to the so-called transverse tensor polarization that is commonly assumed a priori.

Second, gravitational-wave theory is easily contaminated with gauge artifacts. For example, it can predict spurious acceleration of matter with so-called coordinate waves, which are not supposed to carry energy. It has long been known how to deal with the gravitational gauge freedom in flat and symmetric spacetimes; however, the presence of matter typically breaks these symmetries. As a result, it has not been clear even how to define the most basic properties of gravitational waves, such as their energy and momentum, in plasmas and other media. We have proposed a general way to deal with this problem. Importantly, it is applicable not only to waves in plasmas but also elucidates the basic theory of usual vacuum gravitational waves in curved spacetime. 

Overall, the benefit of this project is in that it has yielded the first universal framework for studying weak gravitational perturbations in curved spacetime, with or without matter present. In particular, we have shown that, while the effect of plasma on vacuum gravitational modes is small away from resonances, gravitational effects can significantly affect the properties of some plasma modes, such as ion acoustic modes. In the future, this framework can be used for describing the relativistic energy exchange between gravitational and electromagnetic radiation, which is an important problem of multi-messenger astronomy.

As a spin-off, we have also improved the understanding of how electromagnetic waves propagate in curved spacetime, for example, near black holes. It is widely believed that vacuum electromagnetic waves propagate along geodesics, but, actually, polarization effects cause deviation of the wave rays from geodesics (and also induce rotation of the wave polarization). Using techniques that were previously developed for waves in laboratory plasmas, we have developed the first comprehensive theory of this "gravitational spin Hall effect".

The broader impact of this project is that it introduces methods of well-established plasma-wave theory to general relativity, bridging the two fields. The project has also served as a mentoring vehicle for a PhD student.
